terms.simple: A complete count of every person living in India, conducted once every 10 years.
terms.detail: The Census of India is the largest peacetime administrative exercise in the world. It records not just headcount but age, gender, literacy, occupation, housing, religion, language, and migration status for every individual. The last completed census was in 2011. Census 2021 was postponed due to COVID-19; Census 2027 is now planned (houselisting from April 2026, enumeration from February 2027).
terms.inContext: Census 2011 counted 1.21 billion people across 640,000+ villages and 8,000+ towns

terms.simple: How many people live in each square kilometer of land.
terms.detail: Population density = total population / land area in sq km. India's national average is 382 per sq km (Census 2011), but this masks enormous variation: Bihar has 1,106 people/sq km while Arunachal Pradesh has just 17. Delhi, at 11,320/sq km, is one of the most densely populated places on Earth.
terms.inContext: India's average density: 382 per sq km (Census 2011). Bihar highest at 1,106, Arunachal Pradesh lowest at 17.

terms.simple: The number of females for every 1,000 males in the population.
terms.detail: India uses the convention of females per 1,000 males (unlike the global standard of males per 100 females). A ratio below 1,000 means fewer women than men. India's national sex ratio was 943 in Census 2011, up from 933 in 2001. Kerala leads with 1,084; Haryana is lowest at 879. The skewed ratio reflects son preference, sex-selective practices, and differential mortality.
terms.inContext: National: 943 females per 1000 males (Census 2011). Kerala: 1,084. Haryana: 879.

terms.simple: How much the population grew over a 10-year period, as a percentage.
terms.detail: Decadal growth is calculated between two census rounds (e.g., 2001 to 2011). India's growth rate has been declining: from 21.5% (1991-2001) to 17.7% (2001-2011). This slowdown reflects falling fertility rates, rising education levels, and urbanization. Nagaland is the only state with negative decadal growth (-0.58% in 2001-2011).
terms.inContext: India grew 17.7% from 2001 to 2011, down from 21.5% in the previous decade

terms.simple: The average number of children a woman would have in her lifetime at current birth rates.
terms.detail: TFR of 2.1 is called 'replacement level' — the rate at which a population exactly replaces itself. India's TFR dropped below replacement to 2.0 nationally (NFHS-5, 2019-21). Bihar remains highest at 3.0; Goa lowest at 1.3. Below-replacement fertility means India's population will eventually stabilize and then decline, though population momentum means growth continues for decades after TFR drops below 2.1.
terms.inContext: India's TFR: 2.0 (NFHS-5). Below replacement level (2.1) for the first time.

terms.simple: The number of babies (under age 1) who die per 1,000 live births in a year.
terms.detail: IMR is one of the most sensitive indicators of a country's healthcare quality and social development. India's IMR has dropped dramatically: from 66 per 1,000 in 2000 to about 25 in 2022 (SRS). But the interstate gap tells the real story: Kerala's IMR is 5 while Madhya Pradesh's is 35 — a baby born in MP is 7 times more likely to die before age 1 than one born in Kerala.
terms.inContext: National IMR: ~25 per 1000 (SRS 2022). Kerala: 5. Madhya Pradesh: 35.

terms.simple: The number of children who die before age 5 per 1,000 live births.
terms.detail: Under-5 mortality captures deaths from infancy through early childhood, including those from malnutrition, diarrhea, pneumonia, and vaccine-preventable diseases. India's rate has halved since 2000 but remains higher than the global average. NFHS-5 shows Kerala at 5 and Uttar Pradesh at 59 — a 12-fold difference within the same country.
terms.inContext: India U5MR: ~30 per 1000 (World Bank 2022). NFHS-5 range: Kerala 5 to UP 59.

terms.simple: The number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes per 100,000 live births.
terms.detail: MMR measures maternal deaths during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days after delivery. India's MMR has declined from 370 (2000) to about 103 (SRS 2019-21). The government target is below 70 by 2030 (SDG target). Kerala has among the lowest MMRs in the developing world; Assam and UP among the highest.
terms.inContext: India MMR: ~103 per 100,000 live births (SRS 2019-21), down from 370 in 2000

terms.simple: The economic boost a country gets when its working-age population (15-64) is much larger than its dependent population (children + elderly).
terms.detail: India is in the middle of its demographic dividend window. About 67% of Indians are working-age (2024), with the dependency ratio at a historic low. This window opened around 2005-2010 and closes around 2035-2040. Countries like South Korea, China, and Thailand converted their dividend into rapid economic growth through education and job creation. India's challenge: creating enough quality jobs before the window closes and the elderly population grows.

terms.simple: The number of people too young (under 15) or too old (65+) to work, relative to the working-age population.
terms.detail: Expressed as dependents per 100 working-age people. A lower ratio means more potential earners supporting fewer dependents. India's ratio has been falling (from 65 in 2000 to about 48 in 2024) as birth rates drop and the working-age bulge grows. Japan's ratio is over 70 due to aging. India's is at a sweet spot — but only if jobs exist.
terms.inContext: India's dependency ratio: ~48 (2024), down from 65 in 2000

terms.simple: The percentage of the population living in cities and towns.
terms.detail: India is about 35% urban (2024), far below China (65%) or Brazil (87%). But urban India is growing fast: cities added 91 million people between 2001 and 2011. By 2047 (India at 100), projections suggest 50%+ will be urban. Urbanization drives economic growth but also strains infrastructure — India's cities already face water, housing, and transport challenges.

terms.simple: The percentage of people aged 7 and above who can read and write in any language.
terms.detail: India's definition counts anyone aged 7+ who can read and write with understanding. The national rate was 74% in Census 2011, up from 65% in 2001. The gender gap (male 82% vs female 65%) has narrowed but remains significant. Kerala leads at 94%; Bihar trails at 62%. Literacy is a census measure — it doesn't capture quality of education, only basic reading/writing ability.

terms.simple: When a child under 5 is too short for their age due to chronic malnutrition.
terms.detail: Stunting (low height-for-age) is a marker of chronic undernutrition, repeated infections, and poor living conditions in early life. It affects brain development and lifelong earning potential. India's stunting rate was 35.5% nationally in NFHS-5 (2019-21), down from 38.4% in NFHS-4. That's still over 40 million stunted children — more than any other country.
terms.inContext: 35.5% of Indian children under 5 are stunted (NFHS-5). Down from 48% in 2005-06.

terms.simple: A continuous survey that tracks births and deaths across India between census years.
terms.detail: Since India conducts a census only every 10 years, the SRS fills the gap by continuously recording vital events (births, deaths) in a representative sample of villages and urban blocks. It provides annual estimates of birth rate, death rate, IMR, and fertility rate at state and national levels. The SRS is run by the Registrar General of India and is the primary source for inter-censal vital statistics.
terms.inContext: SRS 2022 reported a national IMR of 25 per 1000 live births
